div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.

div.head: RUSSIA AND HER ARMY
div.p: It is the question of questions at present IN Russia. If the Army goes, all goes. As longs? the Autocracy can rely upon a sufficient number of the soldiers to shoot down insurgents the revolutionists have no chance. You can do everything with bayonets, it has been said, except sit upon them. But the Tsar can sit, uncomfortably but surely. upon his bayonet , unless the hands that hold them turn against him. Then—le. deluge l If the revolutionists can win over, not the whole of the regiments bat a majority of them, or a majority of the men in most of the battalions, Tsardom must come down with a crash. On the other hand, if "order" can be maintained for the next few months, the fabric of society and government can be kept together, and there may be a chance for the program of moderate social reform outlined in the latent Imperial manifesto. Therefore, everything tarns upon this point: Will the Army stand firm?

As a rule, an army does stand. Long experience, in many countries, has shown that the bonds of discipline are capable of resisting the most tremendous pressure. Put a man into uniform, trained and drill him, and so long aa he is paid and can look to his officers ha will obey orders, in spite of every incentive to disobedience. Tell him to shoot down his own townsmen, villagers, kinsfolk—his own brothers and cousin?—and he does it Military mutinies have occurred; bat how rare they are! Religious fanaticism or racial sentiment may produce them, as it did in oar Sepoy army in India in 1857; so will the denial to soldiers of their pay and allowances. But mere discontent and patriotic feeling seem insufficient to cause the spontaneous ebullition. One of the difficulties is that, however disaffected an army may be, it cannot easily evolve an internal movement. A public meeting cannot be held in a barrack square; a revolutionary committee can hardly be formed in a regiment without the sergeants and officers getting to know something about it the arrest of a ringleader, and his appearance before a squad from another regiment, with loaded rifles, is apt to discourage the others. Military conspiracy from within is one of the hardest things to organize.

The situation in Russia bears a rather curious resemblance to that of Austria in this Year of Revolution-, 1848. The monarchy, despotic and reactionary, and dominated by priests and Court favorites, had stirred up a furious effervescence among the populace of Vienna and the peasants of some of the country districts. At the same time, it bad deprived the Hungarians of their liberties, and kept down the non-German populations by her force. Revolution was rife; but it could have been nothing worn than street riots if no aid had come to the Viennese insurgents rom outside. But some of the Hungarian regiment* raised the standard of revolt, others joined them, and presently the whole Magyar army, with many thousands of volunteers, vas in fall much upon the capital. It was civil var then; and the Hapsburg monarchy was so badly beaten that it would have collapsed Altogether it for the intervention of the Tsar Nicholas. A Russian army marched into Transylvania, the Hungarian insurrection was crushed, and the Viennese despotism reestablished. The parallel is striking, and it may even become closer before the end of the crisis is reached.

div.head: SULTAN AND AMERICA
div.p: TROUBLE IMPENDING

There are evidence*, says the "New York Times" Washington correspondent, that the diplomatic situation between America and Turkey, caused by the Sultan's continued delay in receiving Mr. Leishman as Ambassador, is becoming acute- It is apparent that the marked patience shown towards the Sultan's Government is in danger of wearing out, and it is intimated about the Foreign Office at Washington that unless there is a change of attitude within a comparatively short time the result might be the departure of Mr. Leishman from Constantinople, with a consequent severance of diplomatic relations.

div.head: A Rash Youth.
div.p: On the Ridel Farag line yesterday, a native youth jumped from a train before it had stopped, and broke his ankle.

div.head: Fire at Alexandria.
div.p: Fire broke out yesterday in a perfumery shop at Sharia el Kholonsi, and was extinguished by the Fire Brigade. The damage is estimated at 6.000 franks.

div.head: Slave-Trader Caught
div.p: Abdallah El Farg iwi of the Ababdeh tribe, a notorious slave-trader of the Red Sea, has at last been caught by a patrol. He has been sentenced to six years' penal servitude.

div.head: Anniversary
div.p: To-day is the fourth anniversary of the Coronation of H.M. King Edward VII. The Royal Standard or the Union Jack is flying to-day over all stations occupied by British troops.

div.head: Village Birkets
div.p: The Sanitary Administration has given over to contract the work of fitting up the public birkets. Private birkets will be subject to regulations to be drawn op and put into force during the coming winter.

div.head: Policeman Punished
div.p: A council of discipline held at the Cairo Government has condemned a native police shawish to receive 30 lashes and to be degraded to the rank of private, for receiving bribes. The sentence was carried out on Tuesday.

div.head: English Printing In Egypt.
div.p: Messrs. Waterlow Brothers and Layton, Limited, who have been established at Alexandria for some time past, have opened a branch in Cairo, and Mr. Walter West has just arrived to take over the management of this new branch.

div.head: The Cutting of the Khalig.
div.p: The ceremony of the ' cutting of the Khalig'' has been fixed to take place at Cairo on the 25th inst. A night fete will be given as usual at Foam el Khalig, and the Ministries and Government Administrations will be closed on that day.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin recorded three fresh cases at Alexandria and one case and one death at Suez. The cases at Alexandria were those of a young native at Komel Nadonra, a native ghaffir in Tewfikieh-street, and a native porter living at Bab Sidra.

div.head: Mex-les-Balns.
div.p: The latest attraction which has been added to Mex is the ascends of artistic balloons, which take place at the Casino on Thursdays, Saturdays, and Sundays. The Garibaldina Band plays on those day?. Mex still maintains its position as the popular bathing resort.

div.head: Fatal Jump.
div.p: A sad accident occurred on Thursday evening in Cairo, in Hotel da Nil street. A girl of 15 was talking with a neighbor and attempted to jump from her own to the next- door balcony, but missed her footing and fell. She was immediately picked np in unconscious state, and died soon afterwards. The accident took place at dusk.

div.head: Streets "Up' In Cairo.
div.p: The "Pyramids" complains of the roadmending in Cairo, which is being undertaken on so extensive a scale, and in the busiest thoroughfares, such as the Ismalieh and the Place de l'Opera, as to be an obstruction to traffic. This inconvenience, justly observes our contemporary, might well be avoided by taking up smaller portions of the street at a time.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The management of the Casino informs us that a grand night f6te will be given at the Casino on Saturday next. The second ball of the season will take place on the 25th inst. We are informed that the entrance to the Casino on Thursday and Saturday afternoons (P.T. 5) gives free access to the theatre. At the theatre a new ballet, entitled "Li Fioraie," will be prodaced to-night. Mile Depanne and Ml'e Flenry will take part in the vocal part of the programme.

div.head: Revue Internationale.
div.p: The "Revue Internationale d'Egypte" for May has only just been issued and is not to balky as its predecessors. The first place in the number is given to a lengthy article by G. de B. on "La statistique generale de l'Etat et le mouvement de la navigation h travers le Canal deSutz." Marcel Poilay contributes some more interesting 'Souvenirs d'une Engage Volon taire : Belfort 1870 1871," and there is an article in Italian by G. Mundula ou ''Italy and her Alliances."

div.head: The Camels are Going
div.p: Apropos of automobiles, pays the "World, the ubiquitous car i- finding its way into the desert, and the necessary, if not always harmless, camel will, in a very short time, find its occupation gone. It will not be sorely missed; as a means of locomotion it is no1, ideal, and we all know how Mr. Rudyard Kipling has sum med np its character; but there will be drawbacks even to dashing through the desert on a forty horse power machine, trailing clouds of petrol and dust as we go. No doubt, as a result of the increased facilities for travelling across Africa, someone will lay out an eighteen hole golf course in the Sahara, and balloon excursions to Tibet for automobile races will be made a feature of future seasons.

div.head: Hamburg & Anglo-American Nile Company.
div.p: River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head:
GERMANY AND TURKEY
TEUTONIC INFLUENCE WANING
BAGDAD RAILWAY PROSPECTS.
div.p: M. Jean Rodes, the Constantinople correspondent of the Paris "Eclair," says that German influence in Turkey is on the wane. Turkish officials recognize that Germany's friendship has not averted the recent humiliations of the Porte.
The correspondent affirms that the re3onrces for completing the Bagdad Railway are unobtainable. Consequently the completion of the line is improbable before 60 years, if at all.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: High tension is prevailing between Constantinople and Egypt on account of the great hostility shown towards persons arriving in Constantinople from this country. Recently three Mussulman ladies arrived in Constantinople on a visit to relatives, but they were sent back to their country without delay. The wife of the Persian Consul having arrived to spend the summer with her family, was also forbidden to remain in the city. The Persian Ambassador has made strong representations on the subject to the Porte, but his protests up to the present have been of no avail.

div.head: FRENCH AGENCY.
div.p: The "Figaro" announces that M. de la Boolinifcre, French Diplomats Agent at Cairo, will shortly be transferred to Athens, and will be replaced at Cairo by M. Klokukowski French Minister to Peru.

div.head: BRITISH GARRISON CHANGES.
div.p: The 1st King's Own Scottish Borderers will embark at Southampton on the 21st November on the transport Dongola, which will after wards take the 2od Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment from Egypt to India, where they will be stationed at Subathu.
The transport Assays, which will leave Bombay for home on December 7, will bring the 2nd Battalion of the King's Own Scottish Borderers from Aden to Egypt.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p: A telegram from Pera state3 that ordinary passengers and pilgrims coming from Suez and bound for Jeddah and Yambo must undergo five days' quarantine at Abon Saad. The vessels carrying them will continue their voyage after disinfection and "deratisation."

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Alexandria City Police arrested last night an Italian and an Austrian woman, who are believed to be demi-mondaines, in the neighborhood of Mr. hamed Aly-rquare. Both these women were sent to their respective Consulate1. Yonsbashi B'attner, who is in charge of the Morality Department (Service des Mouurs) of the Alexandria Gonvernorat, is displaying great energy in his efforts to purge the city.

div.head: MOSQUITOES AND MALARIA
div.p: In a report to the Academy of Medicine at Paris, Prince d'Arenberg, Chairman of the Board of the Suez Canal Company, says that thanks to the measures adopted, i.e., filling in of marshes, drainage, and petrolising of ditches, the common mosquitoes have disappeared from Ismaiiia since L903, nor is larvae: of the anopbytus to be found in the protected z >ne, which extends westwards 1.000 metres from the first houses of the Arab quarter, and eastwards 1,800 metres from the first houses of the European town.

It was in 1902 that malaria began to decrease markedly, and from that date not a case has been reported in Ismai'lie, where mosquito nets tor windows and beds, which were so unhealthy and uncomfortable in a warm climate, have been abolished.

div.head: TEL-EL-YEHUDIEH
div.p: Attention has already been directed in our columns to the discoveries during the last season of the earthwork camp of Hyksos and the New Jerusalem at Tel-el-Yehudieh, and the Store City at Ramases. Our readers may be interested to learn that the objects from these sites are on view during the present month at University College, Gower street There has been a large attendance.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menrs sailed from Malta yesterday and is dee fete on Sunday at day break, with passengers, mails, and general CM go.
The Messageries Maritime.? S.S. Congo arrived at Marseille* from Alexandria yesterday morning.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN PRESS.
MR. FINDLAYS ACCUSATION.
div.p: The charges brought by Mr. Mansfield de C. Findlay are still the subject of comment in the local Press. In yesterday's issue of "La Reforme" M. Canivet remarks :—

"Some of our native and European confrères have protested, but there is no need for us to follow their procedure for the following reasons. Mr. Findlay is an honourable man and, having brought a collective accusation, he will dot his i's by mentioning the newspapers who have been recipients of the 'large sums of money' or else Mr. Findlay will remain silent, and in the latter case he will acknowledge that he has deceived the Minister by means of fantastic information. Meanwhile, the accusation need not be taken seriously, and it does not deserve a contradiction. In the position in which Mr. Findlay—whom we are pleased to consider an honourable man — has placed himself, he will speak out and will mention the names of the payers and the recipients."

In regard to our excellent confrère's demand that the identity of the personages who gave "the large sums" should be disclosed by the British Chargé d'Affaires, we may mention that such a disclosure would be quite impossible in view of the exigencies of diplomacy. It must be presumed that some deep political reasons influenced the persons who had to disburse these large sums, and great interest attaches to the personalities of these wholesale corrupters of the Press. Whether the total amount was a million or merely some hundreds of thousands of pounds, is a question of little importance; the point is who gave the money? Did it come from Yildiz Kiosque ? Or was the Sultan in partnership with a great European potentate, jealous of England's power, and they together subscribed the vast sums necessary to tempt the Egyptian journalist from the path of virtue? These problems perhaps never will be solved, although of course the identity of the personages must be known to those who are in a position to pry behind the scenes of European politics and their influences in Egypt.

Our position is one of suspended judgment. On the one hand, it is clearly impossible to believe that Mr. Findlay would have made the accusation to Sir Edward Gray had he not been in a position to substantiate his words. This is brought out by the fact that the telegram containing the charges was included in the White Book. The telegram was dispatched on July 5 and the White Book was published on Friday week, so if the accusation had been found to be incorrect, there would have been plenty of time to have prevented its publication as a State document. Therefore, we must believe that there were ample grounds for holding it to be correct. On the other hand, we would be the last to think that our confrères could have deigned to accept bribes, however gigantic they may have been in amount. The temptation was great, and the prospect of spending a huge sum of money in a trip to Europe was alluring. But at the same time our professional amour-propre prevents us from believing it. Sir Robert Walpole declared that he knew the price of each member of the House of Commons, and some cynics go so far as to say that "every man has his price." If this is true (which everyone may decide for himself)—if there is no virtue for which a degree of temptation cannot be found which is capable of overthrowing it—if the question whether the good or the bad spirit shall gain us to its side only depends on which bids highest and offers most prompt payment—then what the Apostle says might well be true of man universally: "There is no difference, they are altogether sinners ; there is none that doeth good (according to the spirit of the law), no, not one." We, however, do not believe that every man has his price, much less any of our confrères, and though we consider that Mr. Findlay must have had the strongest proofs for the charges he has brought, yet at the same time we wish to firmly believe in the incorruptibility of the journalists who are involved in this accusation.

"L'Egypte" remarks:— Nous estimons que dans cette affaire, comme dans toutes les questions où il s'agit des intérêts vitaux de l'Egypte, nous avons fait tout notre devoir. Forts de notre conscience, nous dédaignons toutes les insinuations calomnieuses et intéressées.

A writer in the "Bosphore" concludes as follows: Le malheur veut que jusqu'ici la presse n'ait pas encore un Syndicat pour faire entendre ses protestations. C'était le cas ou jamais pour le Syndicat de jouer on beau rôle. On accuse la presse de chantage et l'accusation demeure puisqu'on ne prouve pas le contraire. Encore une fois qui accuse-t-on ? Je le demande a tous.

"Al Minbar" says:—The fact that Mr. Findlay has included the European local Press, such as "La Réforme," "Le Phare d'Alexandrie," "L'Egypte," "Le Journal du Caire" ("The Egyptian Gazette" naturally excluded) in the charge made against the Egyptian Press with "Al Minbar," "Al Moayad," "Al Lewa," "El Zaher," etc. ("Al Mokattam" excluded), has set us at ease and lightened the weight of the charge. For we can believe that Mr. Findlay may regret the making of such a sweeping accusation. Men like Canivet, Haïkalis, Manse, etc., cannot accept each a charge without asking in a loud voice from the British Chargé d'Affaires how he could say so much. For our part we would ask Mr. Findlay to give us proofs and tell us: What paper was bribed? Who paid it? And who would have bribed it in such an affair as Derishwai? The Moslem Press was charged in the same way in connection with the Akaba question. Germany and Turkey were mentioned somehow. But who bribed them in the Denishwai affair? Is it the inhabitants of Denishwai, the Menoufieh "Empire"(?), or who? We, the editors of the Arabic Press, beg of the British Agency to bring forth those evidences and proofs which have made Mr. Findlay accuse us of corruption. Indeed, the thing is quite unintelligible. From the tone of the "Egyptian Gazette" it may be gathered that it finds the charge a needless one. Is it possible that such men as Blunt or Dillon who worried the authorities here over the Denishwai affair, could have given money to the local Press? Why not say that these men also received money from the much-talked-of agitators in Egypt? But "they" cannot lay such a charge at the doors of those people in England. However, we are waiting to see what our European and native confrères will say on the matter.

div.head: PROBABLE MEETING WITH KING
div.p: According to a rumour echoed by our native contemporaries, the Khedive will have an interview with King Edward in the course of this summer, and it is for this reason that his Highness has chosen a German watering place.

div.head: ATTACK ON IRRIGATION OFFICER
div.p: In connection with the assault on Mr. A. P. Marson, inspector of irrigation, near Kafr Beirab, the Court of Mit Ghamr has sentenced three of the aggressors to Bix months' imprisonment with hard labour, while their father will be tried before the Court of Mansonrah for breach of the rotation rules.

Our readers will remember that, the assault was committed while Mr. Marson was accompanying the fellah to the local omdeh to draw up a process verbal against him for working his sakieh out of rotation. The young men threw him off his bicycle, and while he lay on the ground attempted to strike Mr. Marson, who, however, repelled his assailants, and gave one of them a sound thrashing.

div.head: DROWNING ACCIDENT AT CHATBY
div.p: A party numbering twenty children of various nationalities were bathing yesterday afternoon in the shallows off the Municipal depots at Chatby when, about five o'clock, five of them were drawn seawards by the waves. A shawish was the first to notice the accident, and with the help of another man, succeeded, after some difficulty, in getting them to shore. Two of them were all right and except for the fright and douse, were none the worse; their other three companions were half suffocated, and one of them, a Greek boy of twelve, died at night at the Government Hospital. The other two are in a dangerous condition.

The accident took place within calling distance of the baths, which were crowded at the time, and the shores were thronged as the children were brought to shore. The shallows have a gentle gradient, with a sandy bottom, and where the accident took place—twenty-five yards out—there was no more that four feet of water.

A word of praise is due both to the Coast Guard and ambulance services for their promptitude, but at the same time we agree with the old maxim that "prevention is better than cure," and were some regulation enacted whereby bathers, especially children, should be subject to a mild form of municipal control as to how, when, and where to bathe, these lamentable occurrences might be avoided, or at any rate rendered more rare

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: Egyptian cotton has been in rather improved demand, and quotations of Good Fair to Good Brown are raised 1/16 per lb. Other qualities, and all uppers, are unchanged. In Futures a fairly active business has been done, and the following are the latest values:— Aug. lOd. Nov. 8.59 Febr. 8.38 Sept. 9.50 Dec. 8.47 March 8.28 Oct. 9.28 Jan. 8.38.

American Futures. The Market this week has been very doll and uninteresting, with only unimportant fluctuations. Today's closing values are 3$ points lower for the current month, and 2@2$ point higher for the later positions, than those of last Thursday. There is very little crop news, and that is generally considered of favorable character, but with continuance of rains in certain sections, chi fly in the Atlantic States and Alabama and portions of Texas. The Bureau report to be issued on Friday next, at noon, in New York, and therefore after the close to our market, is awaited with considerable interact. div.head: EGYPTIAN IVORY
div.p: The quarterly ivory sales were held in London last week. They comprised 39$ tons, against 61 tons a year ago. The Egyptian ivory amounted to 17 tons (14 tons Alexandrian, 3 tons Malta description).

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
THE KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE
div.p: Mr. S. M. Robertson, the member for Tyneside, who was one of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's guests at the recent lunch at the Carlton Hotel, and who acted as spokesman for the guests on that occasion, has become greatly interested in this country ever since, judging from the fact that the only two questions on Egypt in the latest papers to hand, are put by him.

On the 2nd last. he asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether the conveyance by sea of Egyptian pilgrims from Egypt to Arabia was made a monopoly of the Khedivial Steamship Company, while natives of other countries were allowed to sail from the same ports by other lines ; and whether Sir Auckland Colvin, formerly financial adviser to the Egyptian Government, was the chairman of the company in question.
Sir E. Grey replied:—The Foreign Office are not in possession of any information on the matter, which is one that primarily concerns the Egyptian Government.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA PAMEL KAMEL
HIS WORK IN LONDON
div.p: Sir E. Grey replied:—The Foreign Office are not in possession of any information on the matter, which is one that primarily concerns the Egyptian Government.

"Egypt is only two days' journey from Europe. Let those Englishmen who are animated by a spirit of justice, and do not wish to see the honour of England sullied, visit the country. Let them go about in the towns, and in the country. Let them see, with their own eyes, how Christians of all nationalities live with the fellahs, and with all Egyptians. Let them convince themselves that the Egyptian people is not fanatical, but that it is desirous of justice and equality, and that it de mands, above all, to be treated as a nation, and not as a horde of slaves."

div.head: THE DEKHELAH OUTRAGE
div.p: Commenting on the sentences in the O'Brien case, the "Globe" says: — The exceptionally severe sentences passed on a couple of native hooligans at Alexandria for bra tally as3aalting s British soldier will, of course, excite the indignant commiseration of the Byles brigade. That spurious sentimentality is too customary among Radicals posing as friends of humanity at large to call for comment. The point of genuine interest is the proof afforded by such drastic punishment that public feeling at Alexandria shares Lord Cromer's apprehensive- ness of coming trouble. In addition to the continues spread of Pan Islamism throughout Northern Africa, there is a special cause on the Nile to agitate the native population. The propagandists of anti-English sentiment constantly harp on it that after the suppression of the Arabi revolt, Great Britain gave repeated assurance that she would withdraw her garrison, and so cease from exercising control as soon as the Egyptian people were qualified to govern themselves. This impolitic undertaking was like so much other mischief, a Gladstonite legacy, and, for once in a way, the subsequent observance of continuity of policy at the Foreign Office produced inconsequence's. Taking occasion from the accession of sympathetic Radicalism to office in the United Kingdom, Egyptian demagogy is now working both on the Nile and on the Thames to bring to an end that regeneration of the country which British control created and has maintained. We do not care to inquire whether this movement is covertly engineered by the Old Turks at Cairo; that is quite a possibility, as they would have everything to gain, and nothing to lose, by re-establishing Ottoman supremacy on the Nile.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.E Ibrahim Pasha Faad. Minister of Justice, has returned from Europe, and will take over the Regency during the absence of H E. Bontros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs, who leaves for Europe on Friday.
The Earl of Cromer is leaving London on October 10'h next to resume his official duties in Egypt. He will travel overland to Marseilles, where he will embark on the P. and 0. steamship Marmora.
Mr. Brunyate, acting Judicial Adviser, is in Alexandria, to receive Ibrahim Pah ha Faad, and will make a short stay here.
Count Antoine de Zogheb, Diplomatic Agent and Consol General for Denmark, is staying at Bagneres de Luchon, in the Pyrees.
Morgan Agha, first eunuch of the Khedivah- Mother, who accompanied her Highness to Stambotfl, has returned here to hasten the arrangements for the Khedivah's pilgrimage to the Hedjaz.

The many friends whom Captain the Hon. H. D. Hawke made at Alexandria daring the time the Leicesters were quartered here, will be interested to learn that his marriage with Mrs. Anne Bamford, of Misterton Hall, was to take place quietly today at St. Mary's Church, Bryanston square.

Our Keneh Correspondent writes:—Mr. A. W. Hazell, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, has returned from his six months' sick leave His health is improving and he is taking over his duties in the Keneh and Assouan provinces. Much pleasure is displayed by the officials and the inhabitants at the convalescence of this popular functionary.
George Nangovich Bey is returning to Egypt about the end of this month for a short visit. The Bey left Carlsbad to-day for Bad-Gastein.

div.head: LE COMMERCE EGYPTIEN.
div.p: IMPORTATION DES TISSUS DE SOIE EN EGYPTE

En comparantle tableau statiatique de 1905 aveo oelui de Janvier 1898, on rests tout d'abord frapp6 par la oroissanca extraordioaira de la consDmmation dea tisau8 de aoie en E_$ypte, conaommation qui a plua qae double dana cea derniarea ann^es et qui, en ae baaaut sur la proap£rit*£ da paya, continuera sa> s doute aa marche asoendante.
NJOS oroyons done utile d'attirer Fattention dea fabriemt? et exportateura de aoieriea aur oet ^tat de chojeB et de leur douuer qaelquej avia dont ila peuvent faire leur profit.

En gdu^ral, l'Egyptien eat peu enolin i l'aionomie, et le souci du lendemain entre poor peu dan8 ae8 pr^oecupationa. S'il gagne beaucoup, il d^penao de nufirue. C'est pour cette raison quo l'usage de8 fitotle? de aoie a'eat r^pandue dana toute8 lea classes do la population depuis l'habitant dea villea jua- qu'ii celui dea pluapeiita villages de 1'iut^rieur ou le cnltivateur ae permet, cheque annie, le loxe de quelquea coatamea de soie taut pour sea femtnea que poor aea enfanta.
C'est ain8i que, auivant le tableau de statia- tique, chaque paya a pria une part plua ou moia8 large ^ ce aurplua de conaommation.

Cette part, rationnellement, aurait dti Stre proportionnelle avec l'importance de chaoun dea paya. Tel, oependant, n'a paa M le cas. Certains paya, en efi'at, a'en 6ont tenus a leara anoiens modules|ai ont qae'qae peu d^laiasai par la mode ; d'autres, au contraire, ont or64 dea articles nouveaux qui ont pla d£s leur miae en vente en Egypte. Cette faveur da conaommatear lea a encourages a pera£v£ e- dana leur initiative, C3 qai fait que la balance penohe en leur favour,et cela, au detriment dea fabrioants qui r^pagnent kimiter leur example.

Nous aommes amours k cette CODS deration par Involution acoomplie par lea fabricanta de aoieriea italiennes en la rapproobant da r^ial- tat obtenu par la fabriqae lyonnaise qai a'eat born6e, en g^n^ral, k la coufeotion de sea modules anciena.

Durant les 5 annties, qui ae aout ^coulees entre 1892 et 1896, la Franca a import^ en Egypte pour la somme de L E. 238.949 de tiasua de aoie en tons genres, ce qui donne une moyenne de L E. 47.789 1/2 chaque amide. L'ltalie, pendant la mdme pdriode, a vendu pour L.E. 33.921, aoit une moyenne annuelle de LE. 6.781 1/2.

Dan8 lea 5»nndea, de 1901 k 1905, le total, pour la Franoe, eat de L.E. 327.501, aoit one moyenne annuelle de L.E. 65.500.Pour l'ltalie, le total eat de L.E. 323.893, aoit une moyenne annuelle de L.E. 64 778.

II ranltede cea ohiffrea que l'dcart considerable, qai exiatait entre les deux pays dana la prem:dre pdriode, a presque diaparu dana la aeoonde, de aorte que la France qui, jaequ'ici, avait occupd le ler rang, s'acbemine prompte ment vera la perte de sa preponderance ai elle peraiste dans aa routine.
Jagqa'ioi la France a imports : Les crepes noirs, les crepes de Chine, la mousseline, les satins, les habaras, les etoffes pour ameublement, les broehes, les brocatelles.
Pour lea trois premiere articles, auenn paya n'a pa entrer en concarrence aveo Lyon qui reate sans rivale dana oette fabrication.

Quant aux autres tiasup, ila ont 6t6 imitds par l'ltalie aveo dea etoffes plus legdrea et, par consequent, k meillear marche, ce qai leur a procure un ddbouohe trds facile en Egypte. Ainai les lampas qui sont d'ane vente conaidd- rable ioi, aont preaqae exolasivement de provenance italienne. Toutefoia, ce tiesa, pas pins que le habara, le satin et la brocatelle d'imi- tation italienne, a peu contribud k revolution que l'ltalie eat en train d'accomplir. Son succds provient d'an nouvel article que ce paya a laucd aar notre place, ily a trois ana, et q i eat entre en grande favour dans h conaommation.

II a'agit des zephirs de soie. C'eat un tissu ldger tantot rayd, tantOt travailld k jour et tantot k groa oarreaox. La France, juaqu'a prd ent, ne beat paa in- tdreasde k cet artiole qui eat appeld, dit on, k aupplanter dana ce paya tons lei autrei tisans lourda tela que lea broehes, les damasses, lea brocatelles. II prdsente, en eflat-, les avantagee auivant8:
lu Dans les climats chauda, comme en Egypte, on donne la preference aux tiasua ldgera et on ddlaisse volontiera lea lourdea dteffes qui aont font gcoantes surtout en ctd.

On nous a oitd tro's maisons italiennes qai,a elles aeales, ont tait depuis 4 ana one moyenne annuelle d'affaires a'dlevaut k an million. La conaommation va toujourseu augmentaat.Ati i de mieax poasser l'artiole,lea fabricanta d'italie envoieDt deux foia par an leura voyageurs aur notre place avec one varidtd de deaains too jours nouveaux.

Parfoia ces desaina ne conviennent pas aux iudigfene9; alors, aidds par leura reprdaeatants et par les olienta eux-mdmes, lea fabricanta combinent qae'ques dispositions aar la base dea tissue qu'ila posaddent ddji dana leura collections. div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS
div.p: NOTICE

The Egyptian State Railways hereby gives notice to the public that the Administration requires 40 pupils—20 from Upper Egypt and 20 from Lower Egypt—who will be trained for the traffic service with a view to to their being appointed to station duties in Upper or Lower Egypt. Competitive examination for the admission of pupils to fill these vacancies will be held on and after the 1st September, 1906, before a Special Commission at Assiout Railway Station for those of Upper Egypt, and at Cairo for those of Lower Egypt.
Candidates must fulfil the following conditions:—
1st—They moat be of Egyptian nationality;
2nd—They must be of good character;
3rd —They must possess the primary corticate of education of a date not previous to 1903;
4th—They must be medically fit for railway service;
5th —They must be between the age of 18 and 22 years;

9th—Candidates astounding the examination will pay the railway fare either *o Assiout or to Cairo. Those, however, who are afterwards accepted will be granted a free pass to the place where they are sent for their apprenticeship.
Candidates desirous of attending the above examination, are required to send their names to the Traffic Manager, before 26th August proximo, enclosing at the same time the following certificates:
1—A certificate of god conduct signed by the Mamour of their district and the Omdeh of their parish ;
2 The customary guarantees;
3—Those Iram Upper Egypt should produce certificates that they actually belong to Upper Egypt, and those of Lower Egypt should get certificates that they belong to Lower Egypt
On the production of the above, their names will be recorded and an entrance card sent to them by the Traffic Manager.

Candidates presenting themselves at the place of examination will first of all be required to undergo an examination aa to medical fitness, and not be allowed to proceed farther with tli3 examination unless they qualify in this.
The 40 candidates, who in the opinion of the Board of Examination are the beat fitted as regard i character and both physical and mental acquirements, will be appointed »lives of the Administration.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The Administration of Wakfa is to sell by public auction, on November 21, between 9 a.m. and 1 p.m., at its office at Bab-el-Louk, Cairo, the whole lot of 12 feddans and parts situated at Manial-el R da, and belonging to the Wakf of the late Ahmed Pacha el Maneikli. The upset price per feddan is L.E. 3,000
Apply to the said office, on any day except holidays for all particulars relative to the sale. On the day appointed, applicants must present themselves at the same office, with a view to tender.
All tenders must be accompanied by a security amounting in kind equivalent to 20 percent. of the total price of the said land.
The Administration reserves to itself the right to accept or refuse any tender.

Applicants whose tenders are accepted most in the course of ten days which are to elapse before they are notified thereof give aa guarantee for the auction price of the land in question, good cultivable lands to be valued exclusively by the Administration.

div.head:
A REGRETTABLE INCIDENT.
JAPANESE RAIDERS SHOT.

div.p: The "Tribune" states that Americans killed 5 Japanese caught illegally fishing off the A'eutian Islands. A ravenne ontter arrived afterwards and captuied 12 others. The reason for killing the men is obscure.
It is understood that the Government will express regret to the Japanese Ambassador for the sammary treatment of the poachers. {P.)
Mr. Bacon, Acting Secretary of State, has gent to the Ambassador at Tokio the substance of a dfspatoh from Mr. S ms, the Government official in Alaska.

Mr. Bacon states that his purpose in sending the despatch is in order to give information, such as the Government has, of the regrettable inoident, the news of which may reach Japan in a distorted form. There is no intention of offering an apology or further regret than is contained ia this despatch, as the State Department regards the Japanese fi-hermen as poachers it they were within the 3 mile limit, which Mr. Sims vouches was the case.
It appears that: the Japanese raiders were caught skinning seals and refused to surrender, thereupon the apeoial agent, Mr. Lempke, ordered the patrol to fire. {Route*)

div.head:
RUSSIAN CRISIS.
COLLAPSE OF GENERAL STRIKE.

div.p: It is finally stated that the general strike has prove! to be a complete failure; the movement never aseumed serious dimensions except here and in Moscow, where it has already collapsed owing to the vigour shown by the authorities in arresting the agitators and dispersing crowds. (Rent#)
The general strike has completely failed. Work is being resomed everywhere, {lavas)

div.head:
FRANCE AND TURKEY.
EXPEDITION TO DJANET.

div.p: Despite the protests made by the Government, a Turkish expedition has seoretly left Tripoli since the 7th July with the objeot of occupying the Tripolitan hinterland. It is expected to reach Djar et in three months, but it is hoped that the French will ocoupy the Oasis beforehand. (Reuter)
The imports and exports of the United Kingdom during the month of Jaly show increases of £3,867,836 and £5,621.911 respectively. {ReuUr)

Mr. Keir Hardie, iu a speech at Dowlais in reply to Mr. W. Churchill's speech on the 7th instant, strong'y advised "the recent convert trom Toryism" not to indulge in vain glorious threats. The Liberal party had already tried and failed, he said, to oust the Labour party, who nevertheless intended to increase their present representation in Parliament. {Reuter
Rear-Admiral Goodrich has baen appointed to sucoeed Admiral Chichester as Admiral and Superintendent at Gibraltar. (Reufir)
The battleship Mikasa, which was wrecked in September last, has been refloated. (Reuter)
Cricket.- Kent beat Sussex by an innings and 131 runs.

Somerset beat Middlesex by 10 wickets. Hampshire beat Derbyshire by 160 runs. Yorkshire beat Lancashire by 107 ruos. Leicestershire beat West Indians by 24 runs. The matohes between Warwickshire v. Wor cestershire, and 8urrey v. Notts were drawn (Reuter)

div.head: A SYRIAN WANDERINGS
SO AMERICAN TOWN SHOWS HIM HOSPITALITY
div.p: The Syrian leper, Rossatt, continues to be bandied to and fro, snys the New York corres pondent of the "Telegrai h," by the different railway companies of the States. Once again he has boon'dumped into West Virginia, whence he started a month ago to get back to Syria, where he hopes to cure his malady by bathing in the Jordan.

During his travels in a railway box car he has been practically dependent upon the charity of the railway companies, which was not always forthcoming. Most of the time he has spent in Ridings, carefally cooped np and guarded by the police, and surveyed at a respectful distance by carious crowds, who seemed to think leprosy can be caught any time within a range of fiDy yards of the viotim.

Ilossatt's malady, as tho doctors point out, is much le?8 communicable than many other complaints, but wherever the boxed up foreigner found himself a sort of reign of terror immediate'y began. The sanitary authorities all exerted themselves to get rid c f the Syrian as soon as possible, and wherever he has arrived the train officials were sammoned for bringing a man with a contagious disease into the town.
To day Roseatt, looking the picture of misery, is reported to be sitting in a field outside the Parkersburg Station, on the Maryland lliilway, without heme or momy, literally turned out to grass.

div.head: GOLD IN THE DESERT
div.p: A terrible story of death in the desert is told by a party of prospeotors who have jnst struggled into PanaminL in Inyo country, California. They came in haD crazed and with blackenel tongues. The heat had been so terrifi J that they had throwo away everything, including their dearly won golL Many of their comrades had perished in the desert. They had passed whitened skeletons, picked clean by the buzzard, with gold scattered beside the bones.

div.head: THE OLDEST MARRIED COUPLE.
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Crocker, of Taunton—supposed to be the oldest married coaple in England have just celebrated the 72nd anniversary of their wedding. Their unite! age is nearly 190 years. They eijoy good health, but are be coming rather feeble and deaf. Mr. Crocker well remembers the rejoicings after Waterloo, and has a vivid recollection of seeing a man whipped throogh the streets of Wintham nearly 90 years ago. The average age of Mr. and Mrs. Crocker and their four living children is a trifle over 76 years.

div.head: THE POPULARITY OF DICKENS.
div.p: The English Bible is the best selling book, and Shakespeare is the best-selling author. Who comes next in popularity 1 There can be little doubt, says the "Book Monthly," that it Cbatld8 Dickens, with Sir Walter Scott a good third. It may be taken that half a million volumes of Dickens are sold every year in English editions, not to speak of those issued in America. Mr. Waugh, the managing director of Chapman and Hal1, says that in the last six years they have sold close upon 2,000,000 volumes of Dickens.

div.head: TRY EARTHQUAKES FOR THE INDIGESTION.
div.p: Earthquakes are the latest core for indigestion. Commenting on the San Francisco die aster, the "Hospital" says : "It is an undoubted fact that a great many men and women who were in a poor state of health before the shock with bad appetite* and defeotiva digestion, are now eating all they can get and digesting it without trouble ; whilst tho mental condition which so often accompanies the dyspeptic state has equal'y improved. The explanation is as simple as it is rational. Them people were fortunately deprived of their trams, alcohol, and luxuries; they had nothing bat simple food, and they ware compelled to take exercise in the open air to get it."

div.head: THE MOTOR-OMNIBUS.
div.p: In their report the Committee on Cabs and Omnibuses say that as many as 25 per oent. of motor-omnibases are in garage undergoing adjustment or repair on any one day. The average daily mileage of ea h vehicle is from 100 to 120 miles; with 75 per oent. of them running, therefore, the average total daily mileage is abont 47,000 miles. That is, in spite of the infancy of this traflio, and the present high percentage of disabled vehicle* the total mileage per annam ofmotor omnibuses in the Metropolis is already nearly 17,000,000 miles.

div.head: ONLY THIRTY GLASSES.
div.p: These hot days have remiuded a corre- pondent of the refreshing story about the brewer's draymau. A chatty old gentleman was conversing with the drayman. "I sup pote," he ii quired, ' you men get a lot to drink during the day?" "Well, guvnor, was the reply, "some days we get only thirty glasses or so, and seine days we get quite a lot."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

A general holiday appearanoe has taken possession of the money market as well as of the Stock Exchange, and tli9 only charge of importance has been a further considerable amount of monetary circulation on acooontof the holiday makers. There is no reason to predict any alteration in the general situation, which points towards continued ease.

The Secretary of the Treasury in America has come to the relief of the New York market to the extent of another 4,000,000 dollars, and he will probably continue to do so. It is not anticipated that there will be any large demand dnring Angast, and the requirements of the last settlement were easily arranged. The Bank position is quite normal for the time ol year, and the reserve would appear to be ample. Sixty days' sight drafts are negotiated to-day 3 per oent., and the disooant market generally, although somewhat firmer, shows no signs of any material advance.
The Stock Market.

In a recent article we referred to Rassia and Sooth Africa as the "B6tes Noires" of the stock markets. This week the remark has been pecuEarly applicable. In the first plaoe, the short period of quietness which followed the suppression of the Dama has given place to serious disturbances in Finland and at Cronstadt, which may at any moment spread to other parts of the Tsar's domains. These outbreak* have revived the feelings of nervousness both in London and Paris financial circles, and the confidence in an early settlement of the troables established daring the latter part of last week has almost en- tiiely disappeared. On the Paris Bourse the pessimism has been even more marked than here, and appears to owe its origia in a a to difficulties connected with the monthly settlemeot, which have again brought the bears.

As regards South Africa, the new Constitution granted by the Government has been a very absorbing topic, and prior to Mr. Chur chill's announcement, business in the mining market was praotically suspended. The scheme was accorded a mixed reception in the "House." There appeared to be a general feeling of relief that "it was no worse for the laok of confidence in the present administration entertained by members had oreated fears that the terms might have been maoh less favourable to British interests in the Transvaal than actually is the case.

Several points in the scheme were severely criticised, notably the Government's interference in the matter of native labour, it being felt that this and other purely local questions should be left to the jadgment of hose directly concerned, viz., the people of South Africa, seeing that they are to be entrusted with the management of theoountry. In the main, however, final opinion on the proposals is suspended pending the verdiot of the Transvaal.

These two disturbing elements, added to the fact that many members have already left for the holidays, have kept business at a minimum all the week, and in nearly all seotions prices are down. Americans are the only active feataro.Rassians showa anbstantial depreciation.
Consols.
The gilt edged market shared in the general set-back, and Consols reaoted somewhat. The market closes firmer, however, Consols having improved to 87£ for the aooount.
Foreign Bonds,

The international market has been in a very unsettled state, the weakness on the Paris Bourse having acted as a very alarming influence. As we feared last week, the optimistic feeling regarding Russian affairs has had but a short existence, and the daily reports from that country of increasing unrest have caused the bonds to lose most cf tie advantage they gained in the recent revival. The Fours are now 7If and the New Script I Of discount, after being 12 disoount yesterday. Japanese have been more or less impervious to the depression, and quotations show litt'e change or balance.
Homo Railways

This market has been dull in the extreme, ard. with two or three exceptions, prices have had a sagging tendenoy throughout. This is somewhat remarkable in view of the excellent prospeots for Bank Holiday traffics, and is in striking contrast to the great booyanoy displayed last week. The only reason that can be put forward to acoount for this is the idle ness dominating most sections.

A great amount of interest has centred in the dividends of the London and North Western, the Midland, and the Great Western, which were announced to-day. The Midland reoommend a dividend at the rate of 2$ per cent, per annum on the Preferred Converted Ordinary Stock, and at the rate of 2f per cent, on the Deferred, making 4 $ per oent. as against 4j per cent, rast year. The surplns is increased ly £! 1,230. The Great Western dividend remains at 3f per cent., but the carry-forward is increased from £28,584 to £42,000.
The London and North-Western rate is 5 $ per cent., with £96,000 carried forward. Last year 5 percent, was declared.
These dividends were received too late to have mnch effect upon the markets, which for the greater part of the day have been character ised by holiday idleness.
Americans

Tbe activity of American railway shares has been a welcome exception to the general gloom New York has keen a strong point, and Throg morton Street has consistently followed the lead established in that quarter. The market has also derived considerable benefit from the announcement of the dividend on Steel Common at the rate of 1 percent, for the half-year. Those shares under the support thus afforded have advanced to 4If and the Preference to 110$. Union Pacifies have been aotivelybid for, and have gained 7 at 162, while yesterday Chicago Milwaukee spurted 5$ points to 192$, but have lost today.
EGYPTIANS

The Egyptian market has been even more stagnant than daring the past few weeks, and there has been soarcely a deal effeoted. With one or two exceptions, prices are anchinged. National Bank* are a shade harder at 25f-$, but Agricultural remain at 9$-f, the Debentures at 92f. Daira Sanieh are 16f-17, and the Deferred 97. Delta Preference Bearer have cot been mentioned and olose 11$. Delta Land and Investment have been rather sellers and leave ofiat3$-§. Uoion Foncifcre are nominally 6$, and Land Bank of Eryptare easier at 8f-f. Daira Sagar keep a very firm market, and have changed hands at 5, closing 5^ ^. Egyptian Markets at If, Salt and Sjda at 1^, Corporation of Western Egypt, at f premium, and Bank of Abyssinia at $ discount are purely nominal, and there is no sign of business in these shares. Bank of Roumania are steady at 9f-10f. Khedivial Mail Ordinary olose l$-f, and the Preference 4$ jj. There is a small enquiry for Delta 4% Debentures round about 102, bat there is no stock on offer.
Mining

Business in this market is almost at a standstill. The announcement of the terms of the new South African Constitution did not create very maoh ex)itemeat( although there was a oertaio amount of satisfaction that the scheme is better than was expeoted. There was a little bear selling, but on the whole the sagging away of prices was dae to the laok of support. Rand Mine? leave off to night at 6jfo and East Rands at 4*V.

Egyptian mining shares have also lost the good lead obtained last week, and there appears to be absolutely no business passing. Nile Valleys have fallen baok to 5s. 6d. Egyptian Options at 1^ and Egyptian Mines at 3*. 9d. are unchanging, but United Africans are rather better at 1$.

div.head: MOUNT TROODOS,
div.p: CYPRUS.

Mount Troodos, Cyprus. A limited number of paying guests can be received by a lady during the summer months. Cyprus is 24 hours by sea from Port Said. Troodos, 5,500 ft. above the sea, is a delightful and healthy place amongst the pine forests, where the troops and Government officials spend the hot season. Terms: 2 guineas a week. For further particulars apply to Miss Young, Nicosia, or to the Editor of this paper. 25, 507-5-2.
TERMS 2£ GUINEAS PER WEEK. P. r further particulars apply to Miss YOUNG, Nikoaia, or to the Editor

POSITION. The pine covered SIOJK-S of Mount Trotidos where Mi.-vs YOI NO has a camp, are aliout 6406 feet alsive the sen : the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Ottu-ials live tin-re during the hot season from alssit June till October.

Homes. Truodos is about 35 miles from the jort of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Platres 31 in. Beyond Plat res the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road from the Capital, Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (ill out 16 miles).
CLIMATE. The climate is very dry and healthy; in the daytime it is delightful ; the nights, especially after the end of August, are often rather cold.

DRESS. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, lmt it is advisable to have some brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woollen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensable.
RIDES. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the season.
EXPEDITIONS. Places of interest to l>e reached on mule or jxmy liack are Kvkko Monastery. Kalopunuioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
GAMES. There is a Tennis Club with two good Courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds
Cilflien. An'English Church Service is held twin- on Sundays at the Regim. ntal Recreation Room.
WATER. The water supply Is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
MONEY. Drafts oil the Imperial Ottoman Bank and English gold and notes accepted

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
